text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide a right to privacy and self-determination. The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives. According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections of the Bill of Rights. For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom of association, the Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering of soldiers in peacetime, the Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home against unreasonable search and seizure, the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination, and the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified rights of the people. It's both fortunate and unfortunate those rights have not been specified. Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities, such as racial and ethnic groups need special protection under the Constitution, particularly to ensure that they have equal access to this nation's political and governmental processes. So, with all these protections, why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without discrimination? The answer is not because of any lack of cases. The Court ducked a number of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggle out of one Virginia case in 1976 by affirming a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons. In short, the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away. Why? Well, because with all of these other holdings setting the trend, the court would appear extremely inconsistent if it decided against gay rights. And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights, despite negative public opinion, the court might undermine its authority and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings. After all, the United States Supreme Court has no army to back up its decisions, nor does it have control of federal funds with which to coerce compliance. Another possible reason for the court's reluctance to handle gay rights cases is that the court's two liberal members, Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan, fear they would be outvoted on the issue. And they've been delaying gay rights cases because they fear a bad decision would be worse than no decision. If Brennan and Marshall are stalling for a time when the court would be more liberal, it is doubtful they will live long enough. Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health. And if Reagan is re-elected, we probably will have an extremely conservative Supreme Court for the rest of this century. So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates, to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year, and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights, for better or for worse. National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco, is a private, non-profit law firm that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation. It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it finds lawyers nationwide who are willing to donate their time to specific cases. As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal efforts. They're all yours. Thank you. I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you about the current gay rights litigation that's going on around the country and what I'd like to do is sort of break it down by different categories and rather than lecture I just assume make it more of a discussion. So if you have questions as I'm going along, feel free to raise your hands and interrupt. Understand that a good number of you are not law students and so I'll try to keep my terms as a general and in the lay language as possible. If you don't understand something I'm talking about, please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can. I'd like to start off first talking about an area which is very important to gay rights advocates. It's an issue we've been working on for about five years and that's the immigration naturalization issue. And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue which I think many of you will find important, which is the rights of gay students in this country. And by no means is this issue settled at all. In the area of immigration naturalization, we won, gay rights advocates, a very important victory in the U.S. District Court in the Northern District of California in the case of Carl Hill versus INS. And the Immigration Nationality Act prohibits homosexuals from entering the country. However, you don't find the word homosexual anywhere in that act. What you find is a Supreme Court decision which has interpreted the language of the act to exclude homosexuals. And the precise terminology that they interpreted was psychopathic personality. Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic personality, they must be excluded from the country. Now the question is, which we raised in the in the Carl Hill case is how do you determine who is a homosexual? It is our position in gay rights advocates that the only way to make this determination under the law is through an examination by a public health service doctor. That doctor must examine the arriving alien and say to that alien, to our gay issue of what is known as class A certificate, then the INS can exclude the person from the country. Now, the government's position is that a person is able to decide for themselves whether or not they're gay. And if they say they're gay, they are gay and can be excluded from the country. This is the issue. The U.S. District Court here in the Northern District of California agreed with gay rights advocates that a doctor's certificate from the public health service must issue. The case involved Carl Hill, who is a tourist, who's here for pleasure and a journalist, a photographer for a London newspaper, a London newspaper. Now, the same issue rose again in the case of Richard Longstaff, which is a case that we have just filed a petition for review in the United States Supreme Court, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision. The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans. Mr. Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas. He's been here about 20 years now. He came here on a valid immigrant visa. He subsequently opened up two boutiques, clothing stores, and hairdressing salons. He employs about 20 citizens of this country. He pays over $100,000 a year in income taxes. And our government has said to Richard Longstaff, you're not good enough to be an American citizen. Why has our government said that? Because Richard Longstaff is gay. And that is the position that the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld. So what we have now is a clear conflict between two circuits. I might have skipped over it. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals here has affirmed the decision of Carl Hill. What we did is file a petition to the Supreme Court asking them to review the Fifth Circuit decision and to resolve the conflict between the two different courts and appeals. We feel that there's a good chance that the Supreme Court will agree to hear the case. And part of the reason is that there's no constitutional issues. We're not asking this court, this very conservative Supreme Court, to create any new constitutional issues of rights for gay people. All we ask them to do is resolve what is essentially an interagency dispute. And it's more of a question of statutory construction. So our petition was filed in that case at the end of January. The government's brief is due on Friday. And the new case clerk at the Supreme Court tells me that the Supreme Court will probably make a decision in three to four weeks after that. So we could be seeing a decision on that soon. Now, here in the Ninth Circuit, the government filed a petition for what's known as a rehearing on the bond, meaning that they wanted the entire court of appeals for the Ninth Circuit to review that decision. And the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition. That came down January 17th. So what we'll find too is that the government will undoubtedly be asking the Supreme Court to also review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I think, to ask for that review is because as a result of our victory at the lower court level, we filed a petition for attorneys' fees in the amount of $340,000. So there's a little incentive for government to appeal the case. In addition, on the congressional level, there's been some legislation that is going to be introduced by Barney Frank from Massachusetts. And we helped him draft that legislation, which would change the exclusion so that it would eliminate the sexual deviants and psychopathic personality exclusions of gay people from the country. The next area I want to talk to you about is the military. The military has a absolute policy that gay people cannot serve. And the only exception to this policy is not really for the status of being gay, but someone who commits a homosexual sexual act. If they renounce that act, they say, Oh, Christ, was I drunk last night? I didn't know what I was doing. It was a mistake. It's never going to happen again. Please let me stay in the military. They can stay in. Other than that, everybody else is out. Now, the progress we've made in the last few years, at least at the discharge, will be under honorable conditions and will be entitled to full benefits. However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career of the service, this can still be pretty severe after you've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits in your particular chosen career and to have the government in fact say to you, well, you're not good enough to fight and die for your country either. We have a test case pending in the Washington, D.C. circuit, in the Court of Appeals now, involved a man who was originally stationed out here at Monterey Language Institute. That's Jim Dronenberg. He's a specialist in Korean cryptology. He had been in the service for nine years. Three months before his discharge, he had been given a $12,000 reenlistment bonus. He had had accommodation after accommodation after accommodation. They thought he was an excellent soldier until they found out who was gay, the victim out. The strategy of bringing the case in the District of Columbia was that by reputation, the District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals is the most liberal in the country. And in addition, the issue had been decided here in the 9th Circuit some years ago by a case that we had brought in Lawson, that's known as Beller versus Lindor. So there was no avenue available for redress here. And the strategy also would be that if we were able to get into the DC court, then that would resolve the issue for all soldiers, because the issue of jurisdiction and venue revolved around where was the defendant located. It was our position that the Department of Defense and the headquarters of the Department of Navy were located in Washington, DC. And the government fought us tooth and nail on this. In fact, two-thirds of their brief, they argued that the court didn't have jurisdiction. And essentially, for the merits of the case, all they did was say, well, another court out there in San Francisco decides this issue, and so it's worth nothing but that they said. Well, we won half that case. We won the jurisdictional issue. We lost on the merits. Now we're in the Court of Appeals, and our strategy, we found, backfired on us, because the odds maybe were 1,000 to one of drawing three conservative judges in which we three of the most conservative judges you could ever want to have. One of them started asking questions about did the right to privacy include the right to have sex with animals? And you have to start off at this level, you can't be too optimistic about the result. One of the other judges who was a Reagan appointee to the bench was a former professor of law at the University of Chicago Law School and a student who did work for gay rights advocates as a volunteer last summer, had this judge as a professor for constitutional law. And when this man came to the issue of abortion rights, he said, I'm Catholic and I have nine children and that's enough said about abortion, let's move on. So, as you can see, we're not too optimistic about that case. There was a really great brief filed American Civil Liberties Union in that Uniquest crowd group or Friend of the Court group. And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale that the military uses for excluding gays and they compared it to the same rationale that the military used to segregate blacks from the service. To say, look, white men are never going to sleep in the same barracks as black men. White soldiers are never going to sleep with blacks. So how can a black maintain control and command respect? And this is the same kind of thing they say about gays and lesbians in the service, that it just isn't going to work out. And what they're doing is trying to institutionalize society's prejudice rather than trying to deal with underlying problems. So it's a very good, very detailed, brief, and very enlightening hope that the court takes some note of it. The paradox to what's going on in the military is that if you're a civilian employee of the military, there's almost, it's almost impossible to get rid of you regardless of what kind of activity you're involved in. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has recently found that a person who is a convicted child molester still could not be discharged from the Navy absent a showing that there was some connection with his job duties in the Navy, what we call the nexus between his activity and his job requirements. So in another area that we find the problem is that people who want to make a career out of the military, they make every effort to get rid of them as soon as they can. And those who want to get out, somebody covers after they're in the service that they realize that their sexual orientation does not mean what they thought it was and they come to their commanding officer and they say, I'm gay. These people flounder around in the system often for a year or more before they're discharged, even though the regulations are are so mandatory, and how we resolve that problem I can't really say, but it really is sort of a schizophrenic kind of attitude that they just can't make up their mind what they want. Other problems that we found now, too, is that the military, in some instances, are trying to prosecute soldiers for asking for a discharge, saying that they enlisted They knew at the time that they enlisted that they were gay, that their enlistment therefore was fraudulent and they were trying to have them prosecuted. There's a case up on appeal on the 10th Circuit Court in Denver and it's been there for some time so you shouldn't see a decision pretty soon in that case. Another thing we find the military is doing now is suing people who've gone through ROTC And apparently they have some kind of program where they subsidize their educational benefits. In the case that came before us last year, there was a person who went through medical school, of course, in the U.S. Army. And then when he finished, he said, I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint, not because I realize I'm gay. So the Army said, well, I think we're going to have to sue you for $60,000 dollars to reimburse us for the cost of re-education. We were willing to defend this man, but he didn't have the desire to go through several years of litigation. It takes a lot for Ford to go through that, and what he did instead was file a bankruptcy. In any case, the military picked up the bill, or for those of you who are working, I guess we all picked up the the bill in a sense, which leads me to the next thing that we've done is, based on some data we've collected over the last couple of years, we can make a pretty good estimate that the cost of separating gay people from the military is at least $20 million a year. That on average, the military separates about 1,800 soldiers a year from the service because of homosexuality, and that based on a recent Rand Corporation study, the cost of training a soldier, through basic training, the first 22 weeks is $100,000. So a simple arithmetic will show that that's $18 billion and my experience is most of the people that are being discharged have been around for a lot more than 22 weeks. What's the situation with conscription where somebody turns 19 and is supposed to go to the post office and says, I'm gay, how does the system deal with that? Well, you probably wouldn't necessarily tell the postmaster, but you would still have to register, and it wouldn't really become an issue until you were calmed up. And at that time, what happens is that you're given a questionnaire to ask you to list all of your childhood diseases and broken bones, and there's a square somewhere that says how you're infected with homosexual tendencies. What happens then though? If you check the box and say you are so afflicted, then you will be deferred. You will not be taken as inducted into the military. You cannot be inducted into the military. If you do not check the box, you could be inducted. However, if you fraudulently, if you know that you're gay and you don't check that box, you are subject to penalties of as much as five years five years in prison and $5,000 if they could subsequently prove the case against you. Let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit. Something that's been in the news just recently was AB1 finally passed both houses and sitting on Duke's desk waiting for signature. What most people don't know in this state is that all that bill does is codify a Supreme Court decision, which already extends sexual orientation, discrimination, protection to all employers in the state. The only thing is that not all employees are covered. And this was the case of gay law students versus specific telephone and telegraph. And I say it doesn't cover all employees because it only covers those employees who are open or out on the job. The employers got to know that they're gay because part of what the Supreme Court of California said in that case was that being out on the job is political activity and that in this state an employer may not discriminate against an employee based on political activity. Political activity is much broader than partisan politics. It goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties, includes political causes, women's rights, labor union rights, gay rights. So what the AV1 does is protect those people who are not out on their job, and it also gives them an administrative remedy by going through the Fair Employment Housing Administration rather than having to file a suit directly in court. Other employment work that we're doing at K-Rights Advocates, one involves a suit against an act named the Helms Bill in Oklahoma. The Helms Bill is essentially similar to the Bridge Initiative that was up here in California a few years back. While the Bridge Initiative was defeated here in California, it's lost in Oklahoma. And we filed a suit challenging that bill and we lost the district court level in Oklahoma. We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals by the 10th Circuit in Denver. We had oral arguments last September, so we're looking for a decision any time in that case. The Helms bill, we call, the main issue was First Amendment freedom of expression. That was the main cause of action. There was also, we raised due process and equal protection arguments, as well as right to privacy. And in this kind of litigation, I'll tell you, for some of you who are law students and don't realize, and the rest of you who are not, we're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat of our pants. I mean, this is new. And when we're in the courts and we're making new law, the gay rights litigation that's going on in this country has essentially taken place in the last 10 to 15 years. 10 years ago, GRA didn't exist, and there weren't no gay legal organizations around the country. And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the books, and it's not uncommon to find all sorts of oppressive legislation in the books. So we don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents. We have to analogize a lot to the struggles that were won in the women's movement into the black movement and other First Amendment types of cases, the privacy decisions that came out of the abortion litigation and the contraceptive litigation. That's what we sort of draw from. Sometimes we make analogies. Sometimes we just make up new theories. You have to go in there. See, we feel, gay rights advocates, we have a very aggressive litigation posture. If we don't go into court and file suit, then we've lost before we've even started. There is, in a sense, nothing to lose by going into court because, in the case of the Helmsville situation, The bill's on the books. And if we lose, the bill's still on the books. So what did we lose? But at least we go in there and fight we have a chance of winning. And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits. There's educational benefits. There's consciousness raising. There's all the press we've got. We've generated a lot of good press. People just cannot believe the situations I've been ascribing to you tonight about the military and immigration, these kind of things happening in America today in 1984. It's just incredible. And so we feel there's a certain value to bringing lawsuits to win all years. And it's making a statement, generally, too, that you pushed this community around for just so long, and now it's your game, but we can play it, too. And we're going to be there, and we're going to fight, and we're going to win. But maybe we're not going to win all the time, but you're not going to knock us out of the ring, because we're going to be right back there fighting every time. And that's what getting rights to advocates is all about. I didn't really follow what your argument was regarding saying you rest your personal time. I assume that you cannot be ganged with a teacher. Well, actually the law is so broad that it could exclude people as well, because the language prohibits homosexual activity and homosexual conduct, neither of which is defined as engaging in what we would call homosexual sexual conduct. It's mere mention, mere discussing of homosexual rights subject to teacher to a disciplinary hearing and possible discharge from their employment. The terms in the law are so vague and so general that it's hard to tell exactly what could be what could be brought within the purview of the law. But essentially, it's expressions. It's talking about and discussing anything about Homestead Trial. What was the name of the case called? Gay Law Students versus Pacific Telephone Terminal. In regard to that case and AB1, what I heard was that dismissing employees on those grounds is prohibited. Wouldn't AB1 also apply to job applicants and to promotion processes? It does specific telephone telegrams. It does. All types of employment related discrimination and promotions, fringe benefits, the hiring process, the whole balance. I haven't taken a look at it in a while. Thousands. Yeah, that's a whole other issue, and I think that's sort of the issue of the 80s, is the is the rights of gay couples. We're going to be doing some gay couple litigation. We did one case already, and we have two pending now, which I'll go into a little bit. One that we're going to do in Columbia, Maryland, which involves the American Automobile Association and their motor club. They offer a discount to married couples, but not to a gay couple or a lesbian couple. And we're demanding that they extend that same benefit to gay couples. The case arose in Columbia, Maryland, which is situated in Howard County. Howard County has a very broad anti-discrimination ordinance. It prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation as well as marital status. It really is a sort of a marital status type discrimination as opposed to sexual orientation. However, gay people cannot be legally married anywhere in the country. So it necessarily impacts on the gay community very heavily. So that's in the administrative process now. And I think whoever loses that is probably going to appeal. So we're looking toward a long court battle out there. We have another case that's in a sort of free adversary position right now down in southern California in La Jolla where there's a gay couple that's been living together for six years. They have a relationship contract that governs their relationship. And they also are having a dispute with AAA, this time with the automobile insurance. And AAA offers apparently a 20% spousal discount, but this couple of course cannot qualify for that spousal So we just might have to see AAA on that issue as well. There are a number of areas where gay people, because they cannot be lawfully married, have fewer benefits and employment fringe benefits and taxation and so on, pension plans. And we don't necessarily, as I said earlier, expect to win all these cases, especially in the beginning. We're looking at at least a 10-year program. But we're going to start raising the consciousness of the insurance industry. There are already at least two insurance carriers that I'm aware of that offer what they call domestic partnership or adult living companion that have different euphemisms. But they offer the plan already. And I think essentially these discounts are marketing gifts. I don't think there's any sound insurance reasons why they're offering them. So it's just going to be a matter of breaking it down. When a few insurance carriers start offering the program, and they find out that it's profitable, I think we'll find many more start offering it as well. Some other employment cases we're involved in, involved a high school guidance counselor in Mad River, Ohio. Marjorie Rowland came out on her job, and she didn't have her contract renewed simply because of her sexual orientation. She won the district court level, won an order for reinstatement and a $40,000 judgment for lost wages. And the school district appealed the case to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati. We had oral arguments in that case last June, so I think we'll be seeing a decision on that one pretty soon now, too. In Minnesota, there's a judge there by the name of Robert Crane Whitten, who's been on the bench for about, excuse me, 19 years, and according to all his peers, is a very able and competent judge, but he's being recommended for removal because he would not take a vow of celibacy. as gay. His sexual orientation came to light when he was arrested and charged with solicitation for prostitution, which he subsequently entered a plea to two misdemeanors, soliciting male prostitutes. Now, what makes the case an interesting one of discrimination is that two years earlier, A straight judge in Minnesota was arrested and fled out to the same charges of female prostitutes. He was given a reprimand and a $250 fine. Crane Winton has been ordered to pay a $46,000 fine and recommended for removal from the bench. And the straight judge was not asked to take a vial of celibacy. Now, the vile solvency comes from the fact that Minnesota has a sodomy statute on the coast. Most people think that sodomy statutes prohibit gay people from having sex. Well, what most people don't understand is that that same statute in virtually every state that has a sodomy statute prohibits all sexual activity other than between a husband and and wife in a missionary position. So even straight people are subject to the same law. In most states, it's a felony. And I'm telling you, these laws are enforced. In Nevada, a man was recently given 22 consecutive life terms for committing the abominable crime against nature. And in that case involved a teenager. And so you could say, well, OK, this is minors. It's not the same. I can assure you, a straight man would have never the same sentence. In addition, another case I'm just aware of in Nevada, where there was a scorned lover who called the police because he walked in on his lover having sex with another man, and the police came out and they caught the people, what we say, flavoring velecto. In bed, this man was arrested, he was charged with sodomy, he was given a 20-year So, I'll tell you, these laws, they're in effect, they're enforced, and even more than that, they're something that we are attacking around the country because they're a great psychological barrier to obtaining gay rights in this country, it's sort of the bedrock of discrimination. How can we give employment protection to criminals? around debate, extending civil rights orders to protect people on the basis of sexual orientation. How can we give civil rights protection to criminals? So this is the kind of thing that we have to get rid of in these sodomy laws. We have participated recently in a national conference of some other gay organizations and sponsored by the National American Civil Liberties Union in New York last fall, where we are going to put together a strategy attacking the remaining 25 sodomy statutes in this country. We're going to go after them one by one and knock them off. We're going to figure out what's the best form. Do we want to be in the state court? Do we want to be in the federal court? What is the correct time? What is the correct mode for attacking these cases? Is it going to be in the criminal context? Is it going to be a civil challenge? And we're going to go after these statutes and we're going to get rid of them. There was a significant victory in the sodomy challenge litigation last year in the case of Baker versus Wade, which came out of the US District Court in Dallas, Texas, which ruled that that sodomy statute in Texas was unconstitutional. The Amarillo District Attorney decided to appeal to appeal that decision, even though the State Attorney General did not. That case is now before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit of New Orleans, and oral arguments have been scheduled for the second week in March. That case, I feel quite certain will also be appealed to the Supreme Court, regardless of who wins. Now, what happened in that case, it's sort of a new twist, was that at the Court of Appeals level, The district attorney said we've got to have a sodomy statute on the books because we need it to control AIDS. Well, at the time that that sodomy statute was passed, I assure you nobody had ever even heard of AIDS. And furthermore, the state and the district attorney did not litigate the AIDS issue at the trial level. So it was our position at the court of appeals level that it's too late, cannot bring up a new issue for the first time at the Court of Appeals level. That same argument is being made in Saudi challenge to the law in Georgia. And there, the case is on appeal before the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. The other case that's pending now that could have some impact, quite considerable impact, in fact, on Saudi litigation in the future is a case which is presently before the U.S. Supreme Court. This is the Uplinger case, which came out of the state of New York. Couple of years ago, by way of background, the New York Court of Appeals, which is the highest court in that state, struck down the Sodom Statute of New York. They said it was unconstitutional. The state applied for a writ of cert to the U.S. Supreme Court. They asked the U.S. Supreme Court to review the decision. the U.S. Supreme Court refused to grant the writ. So the court action became final. What we still have left on the books was a law which made it illegal to ask somebody to engage in deviant sexual behavior, what they call voilering for the solicitation of deviant sexual behavior, which is defined as sonority. So when a man named Robert Uplinger was arrested and charged under that statute, The end result in the court was, well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act, why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act? And they struck down the solicitation statute also. This time, the district attorney in Buffalo appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert to the US Supreme Court when the US Supreme Court granted it. And the speculation was that the reason they granted it was that they had changed their mind about the Monopoly case and they really wanted to review the underlying issues of the sodomy legislation in New York, and in fact that was an argument that was made in the petition by the DA. Now, some events happened since that petition was filed and when the final brief was filed for the state of New York for the District Attorney of Buffalo, he did not argue that the signing of the statute needed to be reconsidered. An interesting twist, too, was that the Attorney General of the State of New York, Robert Abrams, filed a unique brief supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals that the law was unconstitutional. So you had, in effect, the State's Attorney General and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue. NGRA filed an amicus brief in the Supreme Court arguing that the petition was impromptu granted and that they had just threw the whole thing out without deciding it. And what we're hoping is that they are not going to reach the underlying issues, because for one thing, they're not probable before the court. It wasn't an issue in the lower court decision. And secondly, they were not adequately briefed because of, as I said, it was not an issue. The oral arguments have already been presented in that case. We're expecting a decision on the day of this spring. And depending on what happens in that case, it could have a significant impact on your litigation for a good number of years to come. Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area of security clearances. Security clearances are necessary for people, many people who work for the government or work for private industry that do contracts with the government, generally in areas of energy and defense. And what security clearance means is that government says that you are okay to look at classified information and feel that you're not going to divulge this information. There's different levels of security clearance. Gay people over the years had a great deal of problem getting security clearances. And what we found is that the government's policy in this is somewhat inconsistent. They do not have an interagency plan or set of guidelines or criteria. Each agency decides on its own, and there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised. What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person can get a security clearance. Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I'd call them police agencies, the FBI, the CIA, National Security Agency are hanging in there tough and they will not grant security clearance to anybody they know is gay. There's been some recent litigation against the CIA. There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia District Court. It's before Judge Barrington Parker and he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment in that case for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles the U.S. District Court down there involving John Green who was an engineer with a company known as TRW. He's worked with TRW, I believe, for 13 years and he's never had any problems. The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information, divulged any information, but basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to blackmail because he was gay and therefore might divulge information. So that argument breaks down And the person says, I'm not subject to blackmail. I'm open about my sexuality. My family knows, my friends know. There's no big deal to me. I don't know why it's a big deal to you. But to the CIA, it's still a big deal. And they just cannot understand why there might be some kind of, or might not be some kind of problem here. So that case is pending in the U.S. District Court. The government just yesterday filed its brief. They filed a motion to dismiss. They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case based on solemn immunity. They said the government did not consent to be sued in this case. And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government by getting involved in this matter. They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not. So they will be responsible for confounding that on March the 2nd. I'll talk only about two more issues. One is briefly some First Amendment cases that we're involved in. We find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco, we have a Bay Area reporter being censored at a number of prisons around the country. Prisoners want to keep in touch with their gay communities by not being allowed to read these papers. So we're going to be involved in a suit probably and do for a lot of congressional correctional at the Institute in Kentucky and maybe one here at the Lompoc prison and possibly one down in Texas as well. And then last thing that I'm gonna talk about is the rights of gay students. I went to, well I went to several undergraduate schools. I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in the gay political process, and as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events. And Michigan State University is on the main thoroughfare. 40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection. We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us. So we filed an action against the university. We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from some of our sources, post-administration, that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year, because they probably did some pre-service trouble. So the next year, we made an application to put up the banner, and we know we don't have any problems. Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971. Last year, they allowed that gay students be kicked out of fraternities, some of the cousins today. So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot, but it's not enforced. So there are continuing problems going on. We found that there's a school in another school mission called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they're gay. There's a private college in Southern Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework and said this person's gay and he doesn't meet the criminal character requirements of our schools and he can't handle this degree. We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has official, granted official university recognition to the student organization there, but they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any benefits that might go along with official recognition. There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus. And my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate into the law school, gay student organizations. So there are still a lot of lawsuits involved with students as well as many other areas that are important. We can become complacent here in California. It doesn't have a side of the statute anymore. We have a lot of protections. People to a greater extent may be a lot more relaxed. They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community. It's sort of this old hat. But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems. And that's what national gay rights advocates have all got, is writing these new laws and not doing this in the country. Is U.S. advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality if they have not been treated as a concern? Does that seem to be something in California that is sort of a issue? And it's very complicated to consider. Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area. We have not taken on any cases involving that issue. I can't say we've been presented with any. What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for people to come to us, which is not much of a problem. I get calls every day. If they don't go by, they don't get at least one call. So they're concerned about some kind of discrimination or adverse action. But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet. You do talk about this in housing. I just want to point out that this city, Denver, has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together. And this is often used against gay couples. It's a status issue. Is there anything done about it? We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem. That is a way of discriminating against gay people without being so forthright as saying that we're not going to allow two gays to live together. The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure it was necessarily anti-gay, but was intended to keep noise down and to protect sort of family-type environments. Some of you guys like that are very subtle with legislation, some states like Virginia are very blatant.

segments.text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide a right to privacy and self-determination.
The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives.
According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections
of the Bill of Rights.
For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom
of association, the Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering
of soldiers in peacetime, the Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home
against unreasonable search and seizure, the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination,
and the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified
rights of the people. It's both fortunate and unfortunate those rights have not been
specified. Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups
considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities, such as racial and ethnic
groups need special protection under the Constitution, particularly to ensure that they have equal
access to this nation's political and governmental processes. So, with all these protections,
why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without
discrimination? The answer is not because of any lack of cases. The Court ducked a number
of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggle out of one Virginia case in 1976 by affirming
a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons. In short,
the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away. Why? Well, because with
all of these other holdings setting the trend, the court would appear extremely inconsistent
if it decided against gay rights.
And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights,
despite negative public opinion,
the court might undermine its authority
and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings.
After all, the United States Supreme Court
has no army to back up its decisions,
nor does it have control of federal funds
with which to coerce compliance.
Another possible reason for the court's reluctance
to handle gay rights cases
is that the court's two liberal members,
Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan,
fear they would be outvoted on the issue.
And they've been delaying gay rights cases
because they fear a bad decision
would be worse than no decision.
If Brennan and Marshall are stalling
for a time when the court would be more liberal,
it is doubtful they will live long enough.
Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health.
And if Reagan is re-elected,
we probably will have an extremely conservative
Supreme Court for the rest of this century.
So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates,
to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year,
and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights, for better or for worse.
National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco, is a private, non-profit law firm
that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation.
It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it finds lawyers nationwide
who are willing to donate their time to specific cases.
As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal efforts.
They're all yours.
Thank you.
I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you
about the current gay rights litigation that's going
on around the country and what I'd like to do is sort
of break it down by different categories and rather
than lecture I just assume make it more of a discussion.
So if you have questions as I'm going along,
feel free to raise your hands and interrupt.
Understand that a good number of you are not law students
and so I'll try to keep my terms as a general
and in the lay language as possible.
If you don't understand something I'm talking about,
please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can.
I'd like to start off first talking about an area
which is very important to gay rights advocates.
It's an issue we've been working on for about five years
and that's the immigration naturalization issue.
And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue
which I think many of you will find important,
which is the rights of gay students in this country.
And by no means is this issue settled at all.
In the area of immigration naturalization,
we won, gay rights advocates, a very important victory
in the U.S. District Court in the Northern District of California
in the case of Carl Hill versus INS.
And the Immigration Nationality Act
prohibits homosexuals from entering the country.
However, you don't find the word homosexual
anywhere in that act. What you find is a Supreme Court decision which has interpreted the language
of the act to exclude homosexuals. And the precise terminology that they interpreted was
psychopathic personality. Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic personality,
they must be excluded from the country. Now the question is, which we raised in the
in the Carl Hill case is how do you determine
who is a homosexual?
It is our position in gay rights advocates
that the only way to make this determination
under the law is through an examination
by a public health service doctor.
That doctor must examine the arriving alien
and say to that alien, to our gay issue
of what is known as class A certificate,
then the INS can exclude the person from the country.
Now, the government's position is that a person is able to
decide for themselves whether or not they're gay.
And if they say they're gay, they are gay and can be excluded
from the country.
This is the issue.
The U.S. District Court here in the Northern District of
California agreed with gay rights advocates that a doctor's
certificate from the public health service must issue.
The case involved Carl Hill, who is a tourist,
who's here for pleasure and a journalist, a photographer for
a London newspaper, a London newspaper.
Now, the same issue rose again in the case of Richard
Longstaff, which is a case that we have just filed a petition
for review in the United States Supreme Court,
the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision.
The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans.
Mr. Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas.
He's been here about 20 years now.
He came here on a valid immigrant visa.
He subsequently opened up two boutiques, clothing stores,
and hairdressing salons.
He employs about 20 citizens of this country.
He pays over $100,000 a year in income taxes.
And our government has said to Richard Longstaff,
you're not good enough to be an American citizen.
Why has our government said that?
Because Richard Longstaff is gay.
And that is the position that the Fifth Circuit Court
of Appeals has upheld.
So what we have now is a clear conflict between two circuits.
I might have skipped over it.
The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals here has affirmed
the decision of Carl Hill.
What we did is file a petition to the Supreme Court asking them
to review the Fifth Circuit decision
and to resolve the conflict between the two different courts
and appeals.
We feel that there's a good chance
that the Supreme Court will agree to hear the case.
And part of the reason is that there's no constitutional issues.
We're not asking this court, this very conservative Supreme Court,
to create any new constitutional issues of rights for gay people.
All we ask them to do is resolve what is essentially an interagency dispute.
And it's more of a question of statutory construction.
So our petition was filed in that case at the end of January.
The government's brief is due on Friday.
And the new case clerk at the Supreme Court tells me
that the Supreme Court will probably make a decision
in three to four weeks after that.
So we could be seeing a decision on that soon.
Now, here in the Ninth Circuit,
the government filed a petition
for what's known as a rehearing on the bond,
meaning that they wanted the entire court of appeals
for the Ninth Circuit to review that decision.
And the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition.
That came down January 17th.
So what we'll find too is that the government will undoubtedly
be asking the Supreme Court to also review the same issue
in the Carl Hill case.
Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I think,
to ask for that review is because as a result of our
victory at the lower court level, we filed a petition
for attorneys' fees in the amount of $340,000.
So there's a little incentive for government
to appeal the case.
In addition, on the congressional level,
there's been some legislation that
is going to be introduced by Barney Frank from Massachusetts.
And we helped him draft that legislation, which
would change the exclusion so that it would eliminate
the sexual deviants and psychopathic personality
exclusions of gay people from the country.
The next area I want to talk to you about is the military.
The military has a absolute policy that gay people cannot serve.
And the only exception to this policy is not really for the status of being gay,
but someone who commits a homosexual sexual act.
If they renounce that act, they say,
Oh, Christ, was I drunk last night? I didn't know what I was doing.
It was a mistake. It's never going to happen again.
Please let me stay in the military. They can stay in.
Other than that, everybody else is out.
Now, the progress we've made in the last few years,
at least at the discharge, will be under honorable conditions
and will be entitled to full benefits.
However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career
of the service, this can still be pretty severe after
you've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits
in your particular chosen career and to have the government
in fact say to you, well, you're not good enough
to fight and die for your country either.
We have a test case pending in the Washington, D.C. circuit,
in the Court of Appeals now, involved a man who was originally
stationed out here at Monterey Language Institute.
That's Jim Dronenberg.
He's a specialist in Korean cryptology.
He had been in the service for nine years.
Three months before his discharge,
he had been given a $12,000 reenlistment bonus.
He had had accommodation after accommodation after accommodation.
They thought he was an excellent soldier
until they found out who was gay, the victim out.
The strategy of bringing the case in the District of
Columbia was that by reputation, the District of
Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals is the most liberal in
the country.
And in addition, the issue had been decided here in the 9th
Circuit some years ago by a case that we had brought in
Lawson, that's known as Beller versus Lindor.
So there was no avenue available for redress here.
And the strategy also would be that if we
were able to get into the DC court,
then that would resolve the issue for all soldiers,
because the issue of jurisdiction and venue
revolved around where was the defendant located.
It was our position that the Department of Defense
and the headquarters of the Department of Navy
were located in Washington, DC.
And the government fought us tooth and nail on this.
In fact, two-thirds of their brief,
they argued that the court didn't have jurisdiction.
And essentially, for the merits of the case,
all they did was say, well, another court out there
in San Francisco decides this issue,
and so it's worth nothing but that they said.
Well, we won half that case.
We won the jurisdictional issue.
We lost on the merits.
Now we're in the Court of Appeals,
and our strategy, we found, backfired on us,
because the odds maybe were 1,000 to one
of drawing three conservative judges in which we
three of the most conservative judges
you could ever want to have.
One of them started asking questions
about did the right to privacy include
the right to have sex with animals?
And you have to start off at this level,
you can't be too optimistic about the result.
One of the other judges who was a Reagan appointee
to the bench was a former professor of law
at the University of Chicago Law School
and a student who did work for gay rights advocates
as a volunteer last summer, had this judge as a professor
for constitutional law.
And when this man came to the issue of abortion rights,
he said, I'm Catholic and I have nine children
and that's enough said about abortion, let's move on.
So, as you can see, we're not too optimistic
about that case.
There was a really great brief filed
American Civil Liberties Union in that Uniquest crowd group or Friend of the Court group.
And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale that the military uses for excluding gays
and they compared it to the same rationale that the military used to segregate blacks
from the service.
To say, look, white men are never going to sleep in the same barracks as black men.
White soldiers are never going to sleep with blacks.
So how can a black maintain control and command respect?
And this is the same kind of thing
they say about gays and lesbians in the service,
that it just isn't going to work out.
And what they're doing is trying to institutionalize
society's prejudice rather than trying
to deal with underlying problems.
So it's a very good, very detailed, brief,
and very enlightening hope that the court takes
some note of it.
The paradox to what's going on in the military
is that if you're a civilian employee of the military,
there's almost, it's almost impossible to get rid of you
regardless of what kind of activity you're involved in.
The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has recently
found that a person who is a convicted child molester
still could not be discharged from the Navy
absent a showing that there was some connection
with his job duties in the Navy,
what we call the nexus between his activity
and his job requirements.
So in another area that we find the problem is that people who
want to make a career out of the military, they make every
effort to get rid of them as soon as they can.
And those who want to get out, somebody covers after they're
in the service that they realize that their sexual orientation
does not mean what they thought it was and they come to their
commanding officer and they say, I'm gay.
These people flounder around in the system often for a year or
more before they're discharged, even though the regulations are
are so mandatory, and how we resolve that problem I can't really say, but it really
is sort of a schizophrenic kind of attitude that they just can't make up their mind what
they want. Other problems that we found now, too, is that the military, in some instances,
are trying to prosecute soldiers for asking for a discharge, saying that they enlisted
They knew at the time that they enlisted that they were gay, that their enlistment therefore
was fraudulent and they were trying to have them prosecuted.
There's a case up on appeal on the 10th Circuit Court in Denver and it's been there for some
time so you shouldn't see a decision pretty soon in that case.
Another thing we find the military is doing now is suing people who've gone through ROTC
And apparently they have some kind of program where they subsidize their educational benefits.
In the case that came before us last year, there was a person who went through medical school,
of course, in the U.S. Army.
And then when he finished, he said, I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint,
not because I realize I'm gay.
So the Army said, well, I think we're going to have to sue you for $60,000
dollars to reimburse us for the cost of re-education. We were willing to defend this man, but he
didn't have the desire to go through several years of litigation. It takes a lot for Ford
to go through that, and what he did instead was file a bankruptcy. In any case, the military
picked up the bill, or for those of you who are working, I guess we all picked up the
the bill in a sense, which leads me to the next thing that we've done is, based on some
data we've collected over the last couple of years, we can make a pretty good estimate
that the cost of separating gay people from the military is at least $20 million a year.
That on average, the military separates about 1,800 soldiers a year from the service because
of homosexuality, and that based on a recent Rand Corporation study, the cost of training
a soldier, through basic training, the first 22 weeks is $100,000. So a simple arithmetic
will show that that's $18 billion and my experience is most of the people that are being discharged
have been around for a lot more than 22 weeks.
What's the situation with conscription where somebody turns 19 and is supposed to go to
the post office and says, I'm gay, how does the system deal with that?
Well, you probably wouldn't necessarily tell the postmaster, but you would still have to register,
and it wouldn't really become an issue until you were calmed up.
And at that time, what happens is that you're given a questionnaire to ask you to list all of your childhood diseases
and broken bones, and there's a square somewhere that says how you're infected with homosexual tendencies.
What happens then though?
If you check the box and say you are so afflicted, then you will be deferred. You will not be
taken as inducted into the military. You cannot be inducted into the military. If you do not
check the box, you could be inducted. However, if you fraudulently, if you know that you're
gay and you don't check that box, you are subject to penalties of as much as five years
five years in prison and $5,000 if they could subsequently prove the case against you.
Let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit. Something that's been in the news just recently was AB1
finally passed both houses and sitting on Duke's desk waiting for signature.
What most people don't know in this state is that all that bill does is codify a Supreme Court decision,
which already extends sexual orientation, discrimination, protection to all employers in the state.
The only thing is that not all employees are covered.
And this was the case of gay law students versus specific telephone and telegraph.
And I say it doesn't cover all employees because it only covers those employees who are open
or out on the job.
The employers got to know that they're gay because part of what the Supreme Court of
California said in that case was that being out on the job is political activity and that
in this state an employer may not discriminate against an employee based on political activity.
Political activity is much broader than partisan politics.
It goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties,
includes political causes, women's rights,
labor union rights, gay rights.
So what the AV1 does is protect those people who are not out on
their job, and it also gives them an administrative remedy
by going through the Fair Employment Housing Administration
rather than having to file a suit directly in court.
Other employment work that we're doing at K-Rights Advocates,
one involves a suit against an act named the Helms Bill in
Oklahoma.
The Helms Bill is essentially similar to the Bridge
Initiative that was up here in California a few years back.
While the Bridge Initiative was defeated here in California,
it's lost in Oklahoma.
And we filed a suit challenging that bill and we lost the
district court level in Oklahoma.
We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals
by the 10th Circuit in Denver.
We had oral arguments last September,
so we're looking for a decision any time in that case.
The Helms bill, we call, the main issue
was First Amendment freedom of expression.
That was the main cause of action.
There was also, we raised due process
and equal protection arguments, as well as right to privacy.
And in this kind of litigation, I'll tell you,
for some of you who are law students
and don't realize, and the rest of you who are not,
we're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat of our pants.
I mean, this is new.
And when we're in the courts and we're making new law,
the gay rights litigation that's going on in this country
has essentially taken place in the last 10 to 15 years.
10 years ago, GRA didn't exist,
and there weren't no gay legal organizations
around the country.
And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the books,
and it's not uncommon to find all sorts of oppressive
legislation in the books.
So we don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents.
We have to analogize a lot to the struggles that were won in
the women's movement into the black movement and other First
Amendment types of cases, the privacy decisions that came out
of the abortion litigation and the contraceptive litigation.
That's what we sort of draw from.
Sometimes we make analogies.
Sometimes we just make up new theories.
You have to go in there.
See, we feel, gay rights advocates,
we have a very aggressive litigation posture.
If we don't go into court and file suit,
then we've lost before we've even started.
There is, in a sense, nothing to lose
by going into court because,
in the case of the Helmsville situation,
The bill's on the books.
And if we lose, the bill's still on the books.
So what did we lose?
But at least we go in there and fight
we have a chance of winning.
And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits.
There's educational benefits.
There's consciousness raising.
There's all the press we've got.
We've generated a lot of good press.
People just cannot believe the situations
I've been ascribing to you tonight
about the military and immigration,
these kind of things happening in America today in 1984.
It's just incredible.
And so we feel there's a certain value
to bringing lawsuits to win all years.
And it's making a statement, generally, too,
that you pushed this community around for just so long,
and now it's your game, but we can play it, too.
And we're going to be there, and we're going to fight,
and we're going to win.
But maybe we're not going to win all the time,
but you're not going to knock us out of the ring,
because we're going to be right back there fighting every time.
And that's what getting rights to advocates is all about.
I didn't really follow what your argument was regarding
saying you rest your personal time.
I assume that you cannot be ganged with a teacher.
Well, actually the law is so broad that it could exclude
people as well, because the language prohibits homosexual activity and homosexual conduct,
neither of which is defined as engaging in what we would call homosexual sexual conduct.
It's mere mention, mere discussing of homosexual rights subject to teacher to a disciplinary
hearing and possible discharge from their employment.
The terms in the law are so vague and so general that it's hard to tell exactly what could be
what could be brought within the purview of the law.
But essentially, it's expressions.
It's talking about and discussing anything
about Homestead Trial.
What was the name of the case called?
Gay Law Students versus Pacific Telephone Terminal.
In regard to that case and AB1, what I heard
was that dismissing employees on those grounds is prohibited.
Wouldn't AB1 also apply to job applicants and to
promotion processes?
It does specific telephone telegrams.
It does.
All types of employment related discrimination and promotions,
fringe benefits, the hiring process, the whole balance.
I haven't taken a look at it in a while.
Thousands.
Yeah, that's a whole other issue, and I think that's sort of the issue of the 80s, is the
is the rights of gay couples.
We're going to be doing some gay couple litigation.
We did one case already, and we have two pending now,
which I'll go into a little bit.
One that we're going to do in Columbia, Maryland,
which involves the American Automobile Association
and their motor club.
They offer a discount to married couples,
but not to a gay couple or a lesbian couple.
And we're demanding that they extend that same benefit to gay couples.
The case arose in Columbia, Maryland, which is situated in Howard County.
Howard County has a very broad anti-discrimination ordinance.
It prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation as well as marital status.
It really is a sort of a marital status type discrimination as opposed to sexual orientation.
However, gay people cannot be legally married anywhere in the country.
So it necessarily impacts on the gay community very heavily.
So that's in the administrative process now.
And I think whoever loses that is probably going to appeal.
So we're looking toward a long court battle out there.
We have another case that's in a sort of free adversary position right now
down in southern California in La Jolla where there's a gay couple that's been living together
for six years. They have a relationship contract that governs their relationship. And they
also are having a dispute with AAA, this time with the automobile insurance. And AAA offers
apparently a 20% spousal discount, but this couple of course cannot qualify for that spousal
So we just might have to see AAA on that issue as well.
There are a number of areas where gay people,
because they cannot be lawfully married,
have fewer benefits and employment fringe benefits
and taxation and so on, pension plans.
And we don't necessarily, as I said earlier,
expect to win all these cases, especially in the beginning.
We're looking at at least a 10-year program.
But we're going to start raising the consciousness of the insurance industry.
There are already at least two insurance carriers that I'm aware of
that offer what they call domestic partnership or adult living companion
that have different euphemisms.
But they offer the plan already.
And I think essentially these discounts are marketing gifts.
I don't think there's any sound insurance reasons why they're offering them.
So it's just going to be a matter of breaking it down.
When a few insurance carriers start offering the program,
and they find out that it's profitable,
I think we'll find many more start offering it as well.
Some other employment cases we're involved in,
involved a high school guidance counselor in Mad River, Ohio.
Marjorie Rowland came out on her job,
and she didn't have her contract renewed simply
because of her sexual orientation.
She won the district court level,
won an order for reinstatement and a $40,000 judgment
for lost wages.
And the school district appealed the case
to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati.
We had oral arguments in that case last June,
so I think we'll be seeing a decision on that one
pretty soon now, too.
In Minnesota, there's a judge there
by the name of Robert Crane Whitten,
who's been on the bench for about, excuse me, 19 years,
and according to all his peers,
is a very able and competent judge,
but he's being recommended for removal
because he would not take a vow of celibacy.
as gay. His sexual orientation came to light when he was arrested and charged with solicitation
for prostitution, which he subsequently entered a plea to two misdemeanors, soliciting male
prostitutes. Now, what makes the case an interesting one of discrimination is that two years earlier,
A straight judge in Minnesota was arrested and fled out to the same charges of female prostitutes.
He was given a reprimand and a $250 fine.
Crane Winton has been ordered to pay a $46,000 fine and recommended for removal from the bench.
And the straight judge was not asked to take a vial of celibacy.
Now, the vile solvency comes from the fact that Minnesota has a sodomy statute on the
coast. Most people think that sodomy statutes prohibit gay people from having sex. Well,
what most people don't understand is that that same statute in virtually every state
that has a sodomy statute prohibits all sexual activity other than between a husband and
and wife in a missionary position.
So even straight people are subject to the same law.
In most states, it's a felony.
And I'm telling you, these laws are enforced.
In Nevada, a man was recently given 22 consecutive life
terms for committing the abominable crime
against nature.
And in that case involved a teenager.
And so you could say, well, OK, this is minors.
It's not the same.
I can assure you, a straight man would have never
the same sentence. In addition, another case I'm just aware of in Nevada, where there was
a scorned lover who called the police because he walked in on his lover having sex with
another man, and the police came out and they caught the people, what we say, flavoring
velecto. In bed, this man was arrested, he was charged with sodomy, he was given a 20-year
So, I'll tell you, these laws, they're in effect, they're enforced, and even more than
that, they're something that we are attacking around the country because they're a great
psychological barrier to obtaining gay rights in this country, it's sort of the bedrock
of discrimination.
How can we give employment protection to criminals?
around debate, extending civil rights orders to protect people on the basis of sexual orientation.
How can we give civil rights protection to criminals?
So this is the kind of thing that we have to get rid of in these sodomy laws.
We have participated recently in a national conference of some other gay organizations
and sponsored by the National American Civil Liberties Union in New York last fall,
where we are going to put together a strategy attacking the remaining 25 sodomy statutes
in this country.
We're going to go after them one by one and knock them off.
We're going to figure out what's the best form.
Do we want to be in the state court?
Do we want to be in the federal court?
What is the correct time?
What is the correct mode for attacking these cases?
Is it going to be in the criminal context?
Is it going to be a civil challenge?
And we're going to go after these statutes
and we're going to get rid of them.
There was a significant victory in the sodomy
challenge litigation last year in the case of Baker
versus Wade, which came out of the US District Court
in Dallas, Texas, which ruled that that sodomy statute
in Texas was unconstitutional.
The Amarillo District Attorney decided to appeal
to appeal that decision, even though the State Attorney General did not.
That case is now before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit of New Orleans,
and oral arguments have been scheduled for the second week in March.
That case, I feel quite certain will also be appealed to the Supreme Court, regardless of who wins.
Now, what happened in that case, it's sort of a new twist, was that at the Court of Appeals level,
The district attorney said we've got to have a sodomy statute
on the books because we need it to control AIDS.
Well, at the time that that sodomy statute was passed,
I assure you nobody had ever even heard of AIDS.
And furthermore, the state
and the district attorney did not litigate the AIDS issue
at the trial level.
So it was our position at the court of appeals level
that it's too late, cannot bring up a new issue
for the first time at the Court of Appeals level.
That same argument is being made in Saudi challenge
to the law in Georgia.
And there, the case is on appeal before the 11th Circuit Court
of Appeals in Atlanta.
The other case that's pending now that
could have some impact, quite considerable impact,
in fact, on Saudi litigation in the future
is a case which is presently before the U.S. Supreme Court.
This is the Uplinger case,
which came out of the state of New York.
Couple of years ago, by way of background,
the New York Court of Appeals,
which is the highest court in that state,
struck down the Sodom Statute of New York.
They said it was unconstitutional.
The state applied for a writ of cert
to the U.S. Supreme Court.
They asked the U.S. Supreme Court to review the decision.
the U.S. Supreme Court refused to grant the writ.
So the court action became final.
What we still have left on the books
was a law which made it illegal to ask somebody
to engage in deviant sexual behavior,
what they call voilering for the solicitation
of deviant sexual behavior, which is defined as sonority.
So when a man named Robert Uplinger was arrested
and charged under that statute,
The end result in the court was,
well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act,
why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act?
And they struck down the solicitation statute also.
This time, the district attorney in Buffalo
appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert
to the US Supreme Court when the US Supreme Court granted it.
And the speculation was that the reason they granted it
was that they had changed their mind about the Monopoly case
and they really wanted to review the underlying
issues of the sodomy legislation in New York, and in fact that was an argument that was
made in the petition by the DA. Now, some events happened since that petition was filed
and when the final brief was filed for the state of New York for the District Attorney
of Buffalo, he did not argue that the signing of the statute needed to be reconsidered.
An interesting twist, too, was that the Attorney General of the State of New York, Robert Abrams,
filed a unique brief supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals that the
law was unconstitutional. So you had, in effect, the State's Attorney General and a city DA
on opposite sides of the same issue.
NGRA filed an amicus brief in the Supreme Court
arguing that the petition was impromptu granted
and that they had just threw the whole thing out
without deciding it.
And what we're hoping is that they are not
going to reach the underlying issues, because for one thing,
they're not probable before the court.
It wasn't an issue in the lower court decision.
And secondly, they were not adequately briefed because of,
as I said, it was not an issue.
The oral arguments have already been presented in that case.
We're expecting a decision on the day of this spring.
And depending on what happens in that case,
it could have a significant impact
on your litigation for a good number of years to come.
Another area of litigation that's going on
is in the area of security clearances.
Security clearances are necessary for people,
many people who work for the government or work for private
industry that do contracts with the government,
generally in areas of energy and defense.
And what security clearance means is that government says
that you are okay to look at classified information and feel
that you're not going to divulge this information.
There's different levels of security clearance.
Gay people over the years had a great deal of problem getting
security clearances.
And what we found is that the government's policy in this is
somewhat inconsistent.
They do not have an interagency plan or set of guidelines or criteria.
Each agency decides on its own, and there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised.
What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person can get a security clearance.
Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies, I'd call them police agencies, the FBI, the CIA,
National Security Agency are hanging in there tough and they will not grant security clearance
to anybody they know is gay. There's been some recent litigation against the CIA. There's
one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia District Court.
It's before Judge Barrington Parker and he's been sitting on motions for summary
judgment in that case for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles
the U.S. District Court down there involving John Green who was an engineer with a company
known as TRW. He's worked with TRW, I believe, for 13 years and he's never had any problems.
The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information, divulged any information,
but basically what they said was that he was gay and that he was subject to blackmail because
he was gay and therefore might divulge information. So that argument breaks down
And the person says, I'm not subject to blackmail.
I'm open about my sexuality.
My family knows, my friends know.
There's no big deal to me.
I don't know why it's a big deal to you.
But to the CIA, it's still a big deal.
And they just cannot understand why there might be some kind
of, or might not be some kind of problem here.
So that case is pending in the U.S. District Court.
The government just yesterday filed its brief.
They filed a motion to dismiss.
They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case
based on solemn immunity.
They said the government did not consent
to be sued in this case.
And they also said that the judiciary
would be infringing on the executive branch of government
by getting involved in this matter.
They said the CIA had absolute discretion
to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not.
So they will be responsible for confounding that
on March the 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is briefly some First Amendment cases that we're
involved in.
We find that a number of gay community newspapers,
like here in San Francisco, we have a Bay Area reporter being
censored at a number of prisons around the country.
Prisoners want to keep in touch with their gay communities by
not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit probably
and do for a lot of congressional correctional
at the Institute in Kentucky and maybe one here
at the Lompoc prison and possibly one down in Texas as well.
And then last thing that I'm gonna talk about
is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University,
which is where I first got involved in the gay political
process, and as a student, I brought a suit
against the university for refusing
to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts,
shall we say, of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on the main thoroughfare.
40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection.
We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week,
and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it was probably
because we weren't adequately prepared,
because we found out from some of our sources,
post-administration, that they had been warned
by their lawyers not to do that again next year,
because they probably did some pre-service trouble.
So the next year, we made an application
to put up the banner, and we know
we don't have any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city
that has an anti-discrimination ordinance,
which I helped lobby for in 1971.
Last year, they allowed that gay students be kicked
out of fraternities, some of the cousins today.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance,
it's not going to be worth a whole lot, but it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school
in another school mission called Andrews College,
which is trying to kick out two students
because they alleged they're gay.
There's a private college in Southern Chicago
that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student
who's completed all of his coursework
and said this person's gay
and he doesn't meet the criminal character requirements
of our schools and he can't handle this degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has official,
granted official university recognition
to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space
or any funding or any benefits that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students
to get recognition at their campus.
And my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast involved a lawsuit
against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate
into the law school, gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involved with students
as well as many other areas that are important.

That is a way of discriminating against gay people
